speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: SCENE VII. Near Actium. MARK ANTONY's camp.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Enter CLEOPATRA and DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: SCENE VIII. A plain near Actium.

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, and TAURUS, with his army, marching

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: SCENE II. Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Enter MARK ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, IRAS, ALEXAS, with others

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: He will not fight with me, Domitius.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: No.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Why should he not?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: He is twenty men to one.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To-morrow, soldier,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: By sea and land I'll fight: or I will live,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Or bathe my dying honour in the blood

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Shall make it live again. Woo't thou fight well?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: I'll strike, and cry 'Take all.'

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Well said; come on.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Call forth my household servants: let's to-night

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Be bounteous at our meal.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter three or four Servitors

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Give me thy hand,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thou hast been rightly honest;--so hast thou;--

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thou,--and thou,--and thou:--you have served me well,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And kings have been your fellows.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: [Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  What means this?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: [Aside to CLEOPATRA]  'Tis one of those odd

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: tricks which sorrow shoots

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Out of the mind.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And thou art honest too.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I wish I could be made so many men,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And all of you clapp'd up together in

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: An Antony, that I might do you service

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: So good as you have done.

speaker: All
text_entry: The gods forbid!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Well, my good fellows, wait on me to-night:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Scant not my cups; and make as much of me

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: As when mine empire was your fellow too,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And suffer'd my command.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: [Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  What does he mean?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: [Aside to CLEOPATRA]  To make his followers weep.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Tend me to-night;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: May be it is the period of your duty:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Haply you shall not see me more; or if,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A mangled shadow: perchance to-morrow

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: You'll serve another master. I look on you

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: As one that takes his leave. Mine honest friends,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I turn you not away; but, like a master

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Married to your good service, stay till death:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Tend me to-night two hours, I ask no more,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And the gods yield you for't!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: What mean you, sir,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: To give them this discomfort? Look, they weep;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: And I, an ass, am onion-eyed: for shame,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Transform us not to women.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Ho, ho, ho!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Now the witch take me, if I meant it thus!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Grace grow where those drops fall!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My hearty friends,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: You take me in too dolorous a sense;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: For I spake to you for your comfort; did desire you

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To burn this night with torches: know, my hearts,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I hope well of to-morrow; and will lead you

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Where rather I'll expect victorious life

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Than death and honour. Let's to supper, come,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And drown consideration.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt
